title: Covid-19 Restrictions Dent McDonald’s Global Business
sub_head: Burger giant’s U.S. sales improved, but higher costs and tighter restrictions hurt profit
body:
McDonald’s Corp. said renewed restrictions around the world aiming to contain the coronavirus pandemic are hurting its global sales and profit.
The fast-food giant on Thursday reported that U.S. same-store sales grew 5.5% in the fourth quarter from a year earlier, an improvement from the third quarter’s 4.6% increase. Staple menu items sold by the burger company boosted U.S. sales, McDonald’s said.
But tightened restrictions on businesses and indoor dining, particularly in Western Europe, dragged on business abroad, McDonald’s said. Fourth-quarter sales at international restaurants that McDonald’s runs were down 7.4% from a year earlier, improving on the previous quarter’s 10.1% decline.
But overall, McDonald’s said costs related to the pandemic, including spending on safety equipment and marketing, ate into profit during its latest period. The company reported earnings, adjusted for one-time items, of $1.70 a share for the quarter, missing analysts’ expectations of $1.77 a share. Revenue of $5.3 billion for the quarter also came in slightly below projections.
A surge in Covid-19 cases depressed sales across many consumer sectors late last year. For restaurants, the impact was especially acute in places that required them to shut their dining rooms again.
